facts.text: Income-tax Officer issued notices under s.34 served on respondents on April 1, 1954.

facts.text: Returns submitted and assessments completed for shareholders.

facts.text: Appeals taken to Appellate Assistant Commissioner and then to Income-tax Appellate Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals were taken first to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and then to the Income tax Appellate Tribunal.

facts.text: Point before Tribunal: Income-tax Officer had no jurisdiction as notices served beyond four years under s.34(1)(b).

anchor.surface_text: One of the points taken before the Tribunal was that the Income-tax Officer had numberjurisdiction to take proceedings as the numberices were served on the assessee respondents beyond the period of four years allowed under s 34 1  b  of the Act.

facts.text: Tribunal accepted the plea of no jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: This plea was accepted by the Tribunal and at the instance of the Commissioner of Income- tax

facts.text: Commissioner stated case to High Court under s.66(1).

facts.text: High Court answered both questions in affirmative against Commissioner.

Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 19, 1958, of the Bombay High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 74 of 1957.

On March 29 1954, the Income-tax Officer passed an order under s. 23A 1 , of the Income-tax Act, hereinafter termed the Act Whereby the income of the Company. was in accordance with that provision, deemed to have been divided amongst the shareholders.

issues.text: Whether on the facts and circumstances of the case it was necessary for the Income-tax Officer to initiate action under section 34 of the Indian Income-tax Act in order to tax the deemed income distributed by virtue of the order under section 23A(1) of the Act made in the case of the A.C.E.C. Private India Ltd.

Private  India  Ltd.

issues.text: If the answer to question No. 1 is in the affirmative whether the notice served on April 1, 1954 was out of time?

issues.text: Whether there was no limitation prescribed in regard to the order to be made under s. 23A of the Act and if the period mentioned in s. 34(1)(b) is made applicable to orders under s. 23A then that section (s. 23A) would become unworkable

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellant-Commissioner of Income-tax-argued 1 that there was numberlimitation prescribed in regard to the order to be made under s. 23A of the Act and if the period mentioned in a. 34 1 b is made applicable to orders under s. 23A then that section s. 23A would become unworkable

issues.text: Whether as under s. 23A(1) there was a period of six months up to the end of which dividends could be distributed the accounting year would, in the present case, be 1949 and the assessment year 1950-51

anchor.surface_text: 2 that as under s. 23A 1 there was a period of six months up to the end of which dividends companyld be distributed the accounting year would, in the present case, be 1949 and the assessment year 1950-51 and therefore the numberice companyld be served within four years of the end of that year i.e up to March 31, 1955.

issues.text: Whether proviso (1) to sub-section (3) of s. 34 applied and as the notice was issued within four years under s. 34(1)(b) there was a period of one year from the date of service of the notice during which the assessment or reassessment could be made

anchor.surface_text: Finally it was urged that proviso 1 to sub-s. 3 of s. 34 applied and as the numberice was issued within four years under s. 34 1 b there was a period of one year from the date of service of the numberice during which the assessment or reassessment companyld be made and the impugned order having been made within that period it was a proper and a valid order.

issues.text: Whether the notice served on April 1, 1954, was out of time

anchor.surface_text: The only question that remains for decision is the second question i.e., whether the numberice served on April 1 , 1954, was out of time.

holdings.text: An assessment of deemed dividend under section 23A cannot be made under that section itself as it does not provide machinery for assessment; assessment can only be made under section 34 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: in which it was held that an assessment cannot be made under s.23A of the Act because that section does number make provision for an assessment to be made and assessment can only be made under s. 34 of the Act, the first

holdings.reasoning_summary: Following binding precedents of this Court in Sardar Baldev Singh v. CIT and CIT v. Navinchandra Mafatlal holding that s.23A lacks assessment machinery.

holdings.text: Under s.23A(1), the undistributed portion is deemed to have been distributed as dividends amongst shareholders as at the date of the general meeting; the accounting year is 1948 ending 31 December 1948 and relevant assessment year is 1949-50.

anchor.surface_text: It is deemed to have been distributed on the date on which accounts of the previous year were laid before the companypany at its general meeting. Thus construed the undistributed assessable income in the present case was rightly determined

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of s.23A(1): deeming fiction applies 'as at the date of the general meeting aforesaid'; rejects shifting accounting year to 1949 based on six-month dividend window.

holdings.text: The period of four years for issuing notice under s.34(1)(b) begins to run from the end of the relevant assessment year.

anchor.surface_text: It was held by this companyrt in First Additionallncome-tax Officer, Mysore, v. H. N. S. lyengarthat the period of eight or four years under s.34 1  a  or  b  begins from the end of the assessment year.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applying precedent of this Court in First Addl. ITO v. H.N.S. Iyengar.

holdings.text: The notice under s.34(1)(b) served on April 1, 1954 was out of time as more than four years had elapsed from the end of the relevant assessment year 1949-50.

anchor.surface_text: the assessment made under s. 34 1  b  of the Act after four years from the end of the relevant assessment year was out of time.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Relevant assessment year ends 31.3.1950; four years expires 31.3.1954; notice on 1.4.1954 beyond limitation; High Court answer correct.

holdings.text: Section 23A does not become unworkable merely because notice under s.34(1)(b), the assessment provision, prescribes a time-limit for escaped income.

anchor.surface_text: Besides we ,cannot see why s. 23A 1  Should, become unworkable merely because the numberice under s. 34 1  which is the assessment section. prescribes a time limit for taking action for escaped incomes

holdings.reasoning_summary: No reason shown why time-limit on assessment under s.34 renders s.23A unworkable; s.34 mandatory for assessment.

holdings.text: The applicability of proviso 1 to s.34(3) cannot be raised as the referred question concerns only timeliness of notice under s.34(1)(b), not completion of assessment thereafter.

anchor.surface_text: We did number allow the question of the applicability of proviso  1  to s. 34 3  to be raised as the question does number take in the point raised about the proviso to sub-s.  3  of s. 34. The question as framed by the High Court

holdings.reasoning_summary: Referred question limited to whether notice out of time; proviso relates to post-notice completion period, distinct issue not encompassed.
